Patient: I often find myself up at night, thinking about what's going to happen to me...Getting weaker and whatnot. It's just so hard to come to terms with.
    Provider: Robert, I truly understand how difficult it is to face such uncertainties, especially during these late hours when you're not able to sleep. We want to help you navigate this journey as smoothly as possible. While we can't take away these fears, we can provide emotional support and connect you with a psychologist if you'd like. How does that sound?
train.answer:
- Understanding: Good (The provider acknowledges the patient's fear and discomfort)
        - Empathy: Good (The provider exhibits sympathy towards the patient's fear)
        - Emotion: Good (The provider responds to the emotional concerns presented by the patient)
        - Presence: Good (The provider acknowledges the patient's concerns and offers a solution that aligns with the patient's comfort)
        - Clarity: Good (The provider uses an understandable language)

    Provider: Those are very important concerns, Robert. While I can't give an exact timeframe, we know generally your condition will deteriorate over time. But our goal isn't to extend life at the expense of suffering. Our main focus is to maximize the quality of your remaining life, and that means managing pain and other symptoms aggressively. I'll be here alongside you on this journey, focusing on making you as comfortable as possible.

- Understanding: Good (The provider understands the patient's sleeplessness and fear)
        - Empathy: Good (The provider empathizes with the patient's fears)
        - Emotion: Good (The provider acknowledges the emotional stress of the patient)
        - Presence: Good (The provider proposes a comforting plan of action to help the patient)
        - Clarity: Good (The message is clearly delivered)
